Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Photoactivated miRNA delivery for modulation of human adipose stromal cell differentiation

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1254281
Hayes

Modulation of cell and tissue function with microRNA (miRNA), which are small non-coding RNA sequences naturally found in animal and plant tissues, is a promising technique to improve the control of wound healing and tissue repair processes. When combined with adult stem/stromal cell (ASC) therapies these techniques may result in a new regenerative medicine paradigm. Several miRNA and other potential oligonucleotide based therapeutics have been demonstrated to posses potent bioactivity but current state-of-the-art oligonucleotide delivery techniques are largely incompatible with clinical therapies due to toxicity and lack of specific action. This project will address the critical need for a clinically relevant, safe and effective miRNA delivery system which provides temporal and spatial control of activation at the site of diseased or damaged tissue. As a primary objective the project will optimize, a nanoparticle (NP) based, light activated, miRNA delivery system (LAMD) for the light activated spatial and temporal regulation of bone and blood vessel formation using ASC as a model system. A secondary objective is the development of a more cost effective and robust processes for the fabrication of a targeted version of the basic LAMD system. Research into manufacturing processes with improved yields and morphological control will address a critical limitation to the development of therapies using targeted particles.

With the lengthening life span and increasing activity levels of the aging population we expect to see a substantial increase in the number of patients presenting with orthopaedic injuries. Of particular interest are solutions to skeletal disorders, such as bone disunions and non-healing, critical sized defects caused by wear, cancers, trauma or as the result joint replacement. The development of a photoactivated, nanoparticle based, miRNA delivery system that addresses the limitations of traditional miRNA delivery vectors while providing for spatial and temporal control of activity could be transformative for miRNA use in regenerative medicine. This project will provide direct support for several undergraduate and graduate students per year to work on this project as research scholars. The project presents a unique and interdisciplinary opportunity for students majoring in biomedical engineering, chemistry and related fields to build fundamental knowledge and appreciation in the areas of nanomaterial synthesis, stem cell biology, photobiology and regenerative medicine. The outreach components of this project will include K-12, undergraduate and graduate education activities.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Drug delivery vehicles which provide mechanisms for spatial and temporal control of release are essential to improving the translational relevance of oligonucleotide based therapies.  Systems providing spatial and temporal control, particularity if they have are activated by a non-invasive trigger, have the potential to improve outcomes in surgical reconstruction and regenerative medicine by precise control of wound healing and tissue repair processes. 

Several miRNA and other potential oligonucleotide based therapeutics have demonstrated potent bioactivity but current state-of-the-art oligonucleotude delivery techniques are largely incompatible with clinical therapies. This project addresses the critical need for a clinically relevant, safe and effective siRNA delivery system which provides temporal and spatial control of activation at the site of diseased or damaged tissue. As a primary objective the project demonstrated a nanoparticle (NP) based,  light aactivated,  miRNA delivery system (LAMD) for the light activated spatial and temporal regulation of bone regeneration and repair both in vitro and in vivo. The research provided valuable insight regarding; 1)  the biocompatability of nanoscale drug delivery systems, 2) the molecular mechanisms underlying miRNA based control of differentiation and 3) the photophysical processes involved in light catalyzed chemical reactions.

An important finding from this work was the demonstration that miR-148b has de novo osteogenic activity in adult derived stem cells and progenitor cells, indicating it's potential as a therapeutic for bone repair and regeneration. Treatment of adult stem cells with a single dose of miR-148b was capable of driving stem cell osteogenesis in vitro and significantly improving critical sized bone defect repair in vivo.  

This research has led to substantial advances in our understanding of the photophyics of light controlled drug delivery. The kinetics of photocleavage and the release of the therapeutics were defined for several types of cleavage reactions.  Plasmonic enhancement effects led to increases in cleavage reaction rates  across a broad range light wavelengths.  Several new thermal cleavage chemistries were developed based on Diels-Alder structures to provide energy specific cleavage. New compositions have been defined that span a range of initiation temperatures from 37C to 80C. When combined with plasmonic silver or gold particles these new cleavage chemistries create wavelength and flux dependent delivery for multiplexed drug delivery.

Additionally, we have refined a synthetic method to create gold and iron oxide magnetic heterodimeric janus (two faced) particles. The magnetic particles provide two chemically dissimilar faces to conduct two non-competing chemistries allowing for facile targeting and therapeutic chemistries to be combined on a single particle. Combining these heterodimeric materials and the Diels-Alder functionalities (above) led to the development nanoparticle delivery systems that can home to endogenous stem cells at the site of bone defects and delivery therapeutic siRNA when activated by external alternating magnetic fields. This technique promises to provide improved control of tissue regeneration in repair of non-healing bone defects.

This grant has provided direct support for three graduate students and eight undergraduate students during the course for course of the project. Indirectly the project has supported the efforts of four more graduate students and five senior capstone engineering design teams.  Students on this project have engaged in summer outreach and educational efforts to expose K-12 students to fundamentals in nanoparticle synthesis/characterization and nanoparticle based drug delivery systems.

Modified by: Daniel Hayes

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Drug delivery vehicles which provide mechanisms for spatial and temporal control of release are essential to improving the translational relevance of oligonucleotide based therapies. Systems providing spatial and temporal control, particularity if they have are activated by a non-invasive trigger, have the potential to improve outcomes in surgical reconstruction and regenerative medicine by precise control of wound healing and tissue repair processes. Several miRNA and other potential oligonucleotide based therapeutics have demonstrated potent bioactivity but current state-of-the-art oligonucleotude delivery techniques are largely incompatible with clinical therapies. This project addresses the critical need for a clinically relevant, safe and effective siRNA delivery system which provides temporal and spatial control of activation at the site of diseased or damaged tissue. As a primary objective the project demonstrated a nanoparticle (NP) based, light aactivated, miRNA delivery system (LAMD) for the light activated spatial and temporal regulation of bone regeneration and repair both in vitro and in vivo. The research provided valuable insight regarding; 1) the biocompatability of nanoscale drug delivery systems, 2) the molecular mechanisms underlying miRNA based control of differentiation and 3) the photophysical processes involved in light catalyzed chemical reactions. An important finding from this work was the demonstration that miR-148b has de novo osteogenic activity in adult derived stem cells and progenitor cells, indicating it's potential as a therapeutic for bone repair and regeneration. Treatment of adult stem cells with a single dose of miR-148b was capable of driving stem cell osteogenesis in vitro and significantly improving critical sized bone defect repair in vivo. This research has led to substantial advances in our understanding of the photophyics of light controlled drug delivery. The kinetics of photocleavage and the release of the therapeutics were defined for several types of cleavage reactions. Plasmonic enhancement effects led to increases in cleavage reaction rates across a broad range light wavelengths. Several new thermal cleavage chemistries were developed based on Diels-Alder structures to provide energy specific cleavage. New compositions have been defined that span a range of initiation temperatures from 37C to 80C. When combined with plasmonic silver or gold particles these new cleavage chemistries create wavelength and flux dependent delivery for multiplexed drug delivery. Additionally, we have refined a synthetic method to create gold and iron oxide magnetic heterodimeric janus (two faced) particles. The magnetic particles provide two chemically dissimilar faces to conduct two non-competing chemistries allowing for facile targeting and therapeutic chemistries to be combined on a single particle. Combining these heterodimeric materials and the Diels-Alder functionalities (above) led to the development nanoparticle delivery systems that can home to endogenous stem cells at the site of bone defects and delivery therapeutic siRNA when activated by external alternating magnetic fields. This technique promises to provide improved control of tissue regeneration in repair of non-healing bone defects. This grant has provided direct support for three graduate students and eight undergraduate students during the course for course of the project. Indirectly the project has supported the efforts of four more graduate students and five senior capstone engineering design teams. Students on this project have engaged in summer outreach and educational efforts to expose K-12 students to fundamentals in nanoparticle synthesis/characterization and nanoparticle based drug delivery systems.
